title: PTY6202 Advanced Musculoskeletal Practice 2 | Singapore Institute of Technology

meta.description: This module enhances musculoskeletal physiotherapy skills through practical and reasoning exercises, focusing on holistic, evidence-based treatment in diverse settings.

text_lines: Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses
Browse Professional Exams and Preparatory Courses
This module enhances musculoskeletal physiotherapy skills through practical and reasoning exercises, focusing on holistic, evidence-based treatment in diverse settings.

This module is for musculoskeletal physiotherapy practitioners looking to enhance their practical and reasoning skills in established settings, including outpatient clinics such as hospitals and polyclinics, and emerging ones like community rehabilitation centers.

Learners will explore the application of manual therapy methods within a holistic treatment model for individuals with lower quadrant pain and dysfunction. While the skills will be region-specific, assessment and treatment will consider the whole person.

They will engage in diverse activities to evaluate evidence-based and clinical concepts, along with advanced practical skills in musculoskeletal settings. A clinical portfolio will serve as a key reflective tool, documenting the integration of communication, clinical reasoning, and practical skills.

To enhance skill development, clinical reasoning and decision-making, the module includes peer-learning and instructor feedback. Moreover, learners will gain hands-on experience through clinical practice education in a healthcare institution to further advance their musculoskeletal physiotherapy skills.
This module is part of the Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy specalisation track in SIT’s
programme. Completing it offers a stackable option towards earning the Master of Health Sciences degree.
Allied Health Professions Council (AHPC)-registered physiotherapists with at least two years of musculoskeletal practice; or
Individuals managing persons with musculoskeletal conditions
Documents and information you would need to complete this application:
Please upload documents under Online Applications - Supporting Documents section.
Employment support letter (Includes applicant's area of work)*
Recognised BSc degree in physiotherapy registrable with the local regulatory bodies*
Your reasons for pursuing the module (100 - 150 words)
Why did you select SIT over other academic institutions? (100 - 150 words)
What do you hope to achieve at the completion of the module? (100 - 150 words)
Advanced Clinical Reasoning for Management of Lower Quadrant Musculoskeletal Conditions

Principle of selection of assessment and treatment techniques for lower quadrant. Topics include manipulation and mobilisation of specific joints in lower quadrant including, lumbar, hip, knee, foot and ankle
Musculoskeletal Management of Specific Patient Population
Clinical reasoning and management of patients with complex condition
Upon successful completion of this module, learners should be able to:
Apply practical skills with the integration of theory into clinical practice for the management of patients with lower quadrant conditions
Perform clinical assessment and treatment of lower quadrant disorders originating in the musculoskeletal system
Explain clinical reasoning with regard to lower quadrant cases concerning the musculoskeletal system
Demonstrate effective communication with all stakeholders involved in the management of patients with lower quadrant conditions
Lead Professional Officer, Singapore Institute of Technology
Lead Professional Officer, Singapore Institute of Technology

Ms Ho Jiaying is a highly experienced principal physiotherapist with a Bachelor of Science in Physiotherapy from Curtin University of Technology, Australia (2004). She holds dual Master's degrees from the University of Queensland, Australia—Master of Physiotherapy (Sports) (2009) and Master of Physiotherapy (Musculoskeletal) (2010). With a strong passion for advancing the field of physiotherapy, Jiaying is committed to educating and nurturing the next generation of physiotherapists through her role as a professional officer at the Singapore Institute of Technology.

With a primary focus on sports physiotherapy, Jiaying possesses extensive expertise in managing musculoskeletal conditions. Her career spans various healthcare settings, including restructured hospitals and private physiotherapy clinics. She has also worked with elite sporting teams, providing physiotherapy services to a diverse range of athletes, from school-level competitors to elite professionals. Jiaying's experience includes physiotherapy coverage for major sporting events, such as the Badminton BWF World Championship (2021), SEA Games (2015, 2019), Standard Chartered Marathon (2015-2017), and the Netball Super League.

Jiaying's research interests lie in the assessment and treatment of lower limb musculoskeletal injuries in athletes. Her contributions to the field have been recognised through presentations at esteemed conferences, including the World Confederation for Physical Therapy Congress (2015), and her work has been published in high-impact journals like the Journal of Orthopaedic and Sports Physical Therapy.
Associate Professor/Prog Leader, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology
Associate Professor/Prog Leader, Health and Social Sciences, Singapore Institute of Technology

Associate Professor Benjamin Soon specialises in Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy. He graduated with a Diploma in Physiotherapy from Nanyang Polytechnic in 2001, a Bachelor of Applied Science (Physiotherapy) in 2002, a Master of Manipulative Therapy from Curtin University (Perth) in 2005, and completed his PhD in physiotherapy from The University of Queensland in 2013. He is also the first Singapore physiotherapist to complete the faculty fellowship programme from the Singapore Biodesign in 2022.

Currently, he is a full-time faculty at the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT). His research area focuses on musculoskeletal physiotherapy and the application of innovative technology in rehabilitation and teaching. He has received several competitive research grants including two ignition grants from SIT and the innovPLUS challenge award in 2024.

Associate Professor Benjamin is the inaugural programme leader for the Honours Degree in Bachelor of Health Science in Physiotherapy (2016 - 2020) and the Master and Doctor of Clinical Research in Health Sciences programme (2020 - current). Clinically, Associate Professor Benjamin offers physiotherapy consultation services weekly on top of his teaching and research activities at SIT. He has taught and been instrumental in developing all the musculoskeletal modules in SIT since 2016.
Clinical reasoning: hip complex, hip condition
Principles of treatment selection for hip
Physical examination, exercises and advanced manual therapy techniques for the hip complex
Clinical reasoning: knee and knee conditions
Principles in the selection of manipulative therapy techniques and physiotherapy management: knee
Physical examination, exercises and advanced manual therapy techniques for the knee
Clinical reasoning: ankle and foot, ankle and foot conditions
Principles in the selection of manipulative therapy techniques and physiotherapy management: ankle and foot
Physical examination exercises and advanced manual therapy techniques for ankle and foot
Principles of management of neural tissue dysfunction: lumbar spine and lower limb
Principles of selection of manipulative therapy techniques: lumbar region
Manipulation therapy techniques for lumbar region and treatment of lumbar spine and lower limb neural system
Clinical reasoning: pelvic and pelvic conditions
Principles of selection of manipulative therapy techniques: pelvic region
Physical examination exercise and management of pelvic region including real-time ultrasound
Reflection report and case-based clinical reasoning assignment
Learners via the Modular Certification Pathway may use their clinical cases at work, in place of clinical practice, to prepare reflective pieces for their clinical portfolio.
A Certificate of Attainment will be issued to participants who
Attend at least 75% of the module; and
Undertake and pass credit-bearing assessment (worth 6 credits) during the module, which can be stacked towards the Graduate Certificate in Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy
Participants who meet the attendance requirement but do not pass the assessment will receive a Certificate of Participation.
The full fee for this course is S$4,469.00.
All fees above include GST. GST applies to individuals and Singapore-registered companies.

The Graduate Certificate in Musculoskeletal Physiotherapy (Modular Certification Pathway) equips physiotherapists with skills in managing pain and dysfunction using a holistic approach.
Improving Patient Outcomes through Advanced Clinical Supervision Competency

The Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) taps on evidence-based education practices to address the increasing demand for advanced clinical supervision competencies among Allied Health Professionals and improve patient outcomes.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation, Competency-based Education
Shedding Light on Workplace Safety in Social Services
These niche courses equip professionals in social service agencies with the skills to optimise health and safety at the workplace.
Health Sciences, Social Sciences, Workplace Safety and Health
Armed with a Postgraduate Diploma in Sonography, Florence Tan is ready for advanced clinical practice and leadership.
Redefining Thinking and Learning at SkillsFuture Festival

The annual SkillsFuture Festival to promote lifelong learning was hosted by the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) this year on 23 July. Riding on the theme of ‘Design for the Future Economy’, the single-day event featured 53 learning workshops and talks, with SIT faculty staff sharing their expert insights on thinking and learning.
Design Innovation, Leadership and Communication, Health Sciences
With the ageing population in Singapore, there has been a paradigm shift from structured institutionalised care to a more person-centric approach.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation, Design Innovation
As Singapore's ageing population continues to grow, care for the elderly is becoming a pressing issue.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation
This intensive workshop provides theoretical and practical skills in small parts ultrasound, including scrotal, penile, thyroid, parathyroid, salivary glands, and lymph nodes.

This intensive workshop provides theoretical and practical skills in breast ultrasound and imaging of lumps and bumps, including intervention work, advanced imaging techniques, and interpretation of abnormal findings.
This workshop provides advanced theoretical knowledge and practical skills for sonographers in paediatric and neonatal ultrasound, including imaging techniques and diagnostic processes.
Interprofessional Low Vision Rehabilitation: Basic Foundations
This course equips healthcare professionals to manage low vision patients, develop assessment skills, support psychosocial adjustment and more.
Occupational Therapy, Physiotherapy, Nursing, Health Sciences
This course is designed to equip AHP clinical supervisors and educators with the skills to provide effective clinical training to AHPs and students.
Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation, Health Sciences
This course equips occupational therapists with skills in occupational therapy-centric cognitive-perceptual assessments, problem identification, goal setting, and intervention plans.
Health Sciences, Adult and Geriatric Rehabilitation, Occupational Therapy
